incorrect try again try again try again try again try again try again that is incorrect. click here to learn the answer, then come back to try again. identify the liver, in your cadaver. tas k confirm that it is largely located in the right upper quadrant of the abdominal cavity. touch the diaphragmatic surface of the liver and realize that your fingers are on its visceral peritoneum. observe that the falciform ligament tas k is composed of two layers of peritoneum that joins the parietal peritoneum of the body wall to the visceral peritoneum of the liver. in the inferior free edge of the falciform ligament, identify the round ligament of the liver, and observe that it extends to the umbilicus. it is a remnant of the umbilical vein, which brought oxygenated blood from the umbilical cord to the fetal liver. gently pull the falciform flap away from the liver and identify the falciform ligament . remember, the liver develops in the ventral mesentery, so the falciform ligament is a remnant of the ventral mesentery that attaches the liver to the underside of the diaphragm and to the anterior abdominal wall as far inferiorly as the umbilicus . from exercise 10.1, it should make sense to you that another remnant of the ventral mesentery attaches the liver to the gi tract. g4.094 falciform in the shape of a sickle; crescent-shaped remember! ligament, in the context of the peritoneal cavity, refers to small mesenteries that extend between organs or from organs to the body wall correct that's right! the falciform ligament extends between the diaphragm and anterior body wall. it also separates the right and left anatomical lobes of the liver. continue continue continue continue continue continue 11. name the ligament that attaches the liver to the diaphragm and anterior body wall. 10.2 quiz submit

with the inferior border of the liver retracted superiorly, identify the tas k lesser omentum. it extends from the lesser curvature of the stomach to the visceral surface of the liver. identify its subdivisions, the hepatogastric and hepatoduodenal ligaments . hepatogastric hepato = related to the liver; gastric = related to the stomach; the hepatogastric ligament is named according to its attachments hepatoduodenal hepato = related to the liver; duodenal = related to the duodenum; hepatoduodenal ligament is also named according to its attachments the lesser omentum is a derivative of the ventral mesentery that connects the visceral peritoneum of the stomach with that of the liver. it contains within its layers blood vessels that supply the stomach and liver, as well as ducts which convey the exocrine secretions of the liver to the duodenum. using your finger, trace the attachment of the lesser omentum to the lesser curvature of the stomach. here, within the layers of the lesser omentum, are the left and right gastric arteries. you will soon dissect these arteries of the foregut. from what you know about the blood supply to the foregut, what branch of the abdominal aorta supplies blood to the right and left gastric arteries ? the celiac trunk yes, iâ€™m flogging a dead horse. g4.057 incorrect try again try again try again try again try again try again that is incorrect. click here to learn the answer, then come back to try again. correct that's right! the hepatogastric ligament is the portion of the lesser omentum that extends between the lesser curvature of the stomach and the liver. continue continue continue continue continue continue 12. name the subdivision of the lesser omentum that stretches between the lesser curvature of the stomach and the liver. 10.2 quiz submit

incorrect try again try again try again try again try again try again that is incorrect. click here to learn the answer, then come back to try again. the spleen is located in the upper left quadrant, and, as illustrated in the accompanying cross section, it is posterior to the stomach. reach behind the stomach tas k with your right hand and feel for the spleen . it is an intraperitoneal organ with a smooth surface and should fit in your hand, unless it is enlarged. gently reflect the stomach to the right side and try to see the spleen. it will be deep red to purple in colour because of its rich blood supply. the hepatic artery proper, common bile duct and hepatic portal vein in the hepatoduodenal ligament of the lesser omentum! abdominal cross-section from below. g4.054 this is most easily done from the cadaverâ€™s right side. correct that's right! the spleen is in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen. continue continue continue continue continue continue 13. in what quadrant of the abdomen is the spleen located? 10.2 quiz submit

incorrect try again try again try again try again try again try again that is incorrect. click here to learn the answer, then come back to try again. with the greater omentum tas k reflected superiorly, identify the large intestine and its components: the cecum and ileocecal junction in the lower right quadrant the ascending colon the transverse colon the descending colon the sigmoid colon observe that both tas k the ascending and descending colons are fixed in place to the posterior abdominal wall, as these portions of the gi tract are secondarily retroperitoneal. identify the transverse mesocolon tas k grantâ€™s atlas fig 2.42 and the sigmoid mesocolon, which are the mesenteries of the transverse and sigmoid colons, respectively, and contain the blood vessels, nerves and lymphatics that supply these portions of the gi tract. because they have a mesentery, these portions of the large intestine are intraperitoneal. correct that's right! the ascending and descending colon are secondarily retroperitoneal. continue continue continue continue continue continue 15. from proximal to distal, the two parts of the large intestine that are secondarily retroperitoneal are the _____________ and _____________ colon. 10.2 quiz submit

incorrect try again try again try again try again try again try again that is incorrect. click here to learn the answer, then come back to try again. identify the right and left lobes of the liver, separated by the falciform ligament. tas k slide your hand into the right subphrenic space . notice that the subphrenic space is a dead end; i.e. you canâ€™t reach over to the posterior aspect of the liver. your fingers have come up against the right coronary ligament , a peritoneal reflection that attaches the liver to the underside of the diaphragm. slide your hand into the tas k left subphrenic space. it, too, is a dead end, limited by the left coronary ligament. identify the gall bladder, also located in the right upper quadrant, extending out from under the inferior border of the liver. confirm its relationship adjacent to the 9th costal cartilage in the right midclavicular line. remember: the liver and gallbladder are foregut derivatives which develop in its ventral mesentery. from which branch of the abdominal aorta does their blood supply originate? think first, and then click here for the answer: subphrenic sub=below; phrenic=having to do with the diaphragm; the sub-phrenic space is between the diaphragm and the liver why is it the â€œcoronaryâ€ ligament? it runs in the coronal plane, across the top of the liver like a crown. g4.094 foregut derivatives receive blood from branches of the celiac trunk. correct that's right! the coronary ligaments are the derivatives of the ventral mesentery that extends between the liver and the underside of the diaphragm in the coronal plane. continue continue continue continue continue continue 16. the ____________ ligaments run from left to right across the superior surface of the liver and attach it to the diaphragm. 10.2 quiz submit

incorrect try again try again try again try again try again try again that is incorrect. click here to learn the answer, then come back to try again. continue to remove serous membrane from the anterior surface of the hepatoduodenal ligament to expose the hepatic artery info: it is very thin-walled carefully, using blunt dissection , tas k info: i suggest large forceps and either a blunt probe or large, closed scissors proper and the common bile duct. the artery is medial to the duct. posterior to these two structures, you will encounter the hepatic portal vein. the artery is robust, but the bile duct and portal vein are thin-walled, so exercise particular caution in cleaning these latter two structures. trace the bile duct toward the liver and gall bladder, dissecting carefully as you go . find the point at which the common bile duct is formed by the union of the cystic duct, which drains the gall bladder, and the common hepatic duct, which drains the liver. continue to dissect the common hepatic duct toward the porta hepatis until you observe its formation from the union of the right and left hepatic ducts. correct that's right! the hepatic artery proper branches from the common hepatic artery to ascend to the porta hepatis. continue continue continue continue continue continue 1. identify a. 10.3 quiz submit

incorrect try again try again try again try again try again try again that is incorrect. click here to learn the answer, then come back to try again. dissection , remove the serous membrane from the anterior surface of the lesser omentum on the right side carefully, using blunt tas k info: i suggest large forceps and either a blunt probe or large, closed scissors of the lesser curvature of the stomach. running parallel to the lesser curvature, and about 1 cm from it, you will encounter the right gastric artery. trace the right gastric artery to the right, and into the hepatogastric ligament, to find its origin, dissecting the serous membrane carefully as you go. the right gastric artery will lead you to either the common hepatic artery or the hepatic artery proper. you will start the dissection by exposing the right gastric artery located between the serous layers of the lesser omentum, along the right side of the lesser curvature of the stomach. the reason we start with this vessel is because it is small and easily broken. once identified, you will trace it toward its origin from either the hepatic artery proper or the common hepatic artery . info: its origin is variable. correct that's right! in this image, the right gastric artery is seen to branch from the hepatic artery proper and descend to the lesser curvature of the stomach. continue continue continue continue continue continue 2. identify a. 10.3 quiz submit
